ideology_summary: Anti-capitalist, anti-establishment, and deeply skeptical of both political parties. Views power as self-serving, believes government is broken, and wants people out of each other’s personal lives while the system itself is rebuilt.
summary_chunks: The Market of Masks is an allegory about a night market split into red and blue stalls that sell the crowd a fight.
The balcony above owns both sides, counts the coins, and keeps the market full while the crowd turns on itself.
The stalls are mirrors, not enemies, trading colors every few years while the same power stays in place.
When scarves stop working, the market weaponizes personal life to keep people distracted from the rigged game.
The only exit is to stop choosing lanterns and build a system that doesn’t reward rage and spectacle.
lesson: The market sells you a fight so the balcony can keep counting.
Red and blue are mirrors, not enemies.
Personal battles are bait to hide the coins leaving your pocket.
You don’t have to pick a lantern. You can build another way.
A system that profits from rage will always manufacture it.
subtitle: In which the traveler learns the city isn’t split in two — it’s sold in two.
